awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultural Dimensions of Dementia and Aging in Indigenous Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Dementia is a neurological impairment characterized by a decline in memory and other cognitive abilities. As a major public health concern, officials have categorized dementia as a new epidemic. Memory loss acutely appears to be of increasing concern for Indigenous people, for whom respect and care for the elderly are built into the fabric of their communities. However, few have observed the experiences and conceptions of dementia within Indigenous contexts. Accordingly, this project asks how Indigenous people come to experience and understand the changes associated with aging and neurological impairment? How is Indigenous understanding of memory loss affected by socioeconomic constraints, and different cultural perspectives of age and memory? In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in scientific methods, this award will enable findings to be shared with Indigenous communities, health professionals, academics, governmental, and non-governmental institutions invested in improving health disparities of Indigenous people. The project also broadens the participation of groups underrepresented in science. 

Through a combination of participant observation, and semi-structured interviews with family members of dementia patients, medical professionals and intermediaries, and document analysis, the investigators will examine how dementia is locally constructed in Indigenous communities.  Specifically, they will examine how Indigenous women negotiate local understandings of dementia and care for their elderly within emerging medical dementia frameworks outlined by the state. This project seeks to contribute to a growing body of accessible public knowledge on practices and policies that target healthcare practices among Indigenous people. A better understanding of the social construction of dementia can provide a backdrop for wide-ranging implications to address dementia care, policies, and research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions, or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

As there is a staggering increase of dementia cases among the elderly worldwide, understanding how dementia and aging are perceived and cared for in culturally diverse communities is crucial. Knowledge about experiences of aging and dementia is particularly lacking for Indigenous communities. This research answered questions left still open by previous scholarship in medical anthropology, specifically, this research investigated how Indigenous women from the community of Teotitlan del Valle, Oaxaca mobilized public health access for elders with dementia. The representation of Indigenous women's activism is examined through a study of their forms of social organizing at the intersection of both social movements and health activism. Indigenous women have been far from silent about community needs and priorities, but their activism continues to be overlooked. 

This research consisted of 12-month ethnographic fieldwork in Teotitlan del Valle, Oaxaca, Mexico. As a response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the CO-PI compiled data using a plethora of qualitative methods that posed no risk to the interlocutors involved in the research, this includes the use of social networking websites, online message boards, and the use of public radio broadcasts locally and online as tools in the collection of data. Informal WhatsApp interviews were conducted with Indigenous women activists that either worked at the communities' clinic or were the primary elder caregivers. 

Outmigration in indigenous communities in Mexico has significantly altered family structures. In the traditional scenario of Teotitlan del Valle, it is the man who usually leaves his home village in the search of better economic opportunities for his family. In this context, women left behind have become the only support and guide of the family. This study suggests that Mexico's current health care system reinforce the role of women as primary caregiver, providing them with further responsibilities, including navigating violent bureaucratic procedures to apply for resources to support the medical needs of the elderly. Interviews with women caretakers revealed that the bureaucratic routes for gaining access to basic healthcare created an experience of anxiety over seeking care. On this note, during this research, the town's only clinic closed down, leaving the community with no medical resources to treat the community's COVID-19 cases or other chronic conditions. The lack of access to health services came at a high price, that is, in 6 months over 50 people died, an unprecedented number of deaths in the history of the town. Thus, this study suggests that the pandemic not only aggravated the pre-existing inequalities in Indigenous communities' access but worsen the bureaucratic routes for gaining basic medical care, leading women to care for their elderly at home and rely only on traditional herbal medicine.  

This study contributes to debates within anthropology on aging bodies, dementia, and women labor care by studying how care is negotiated outside clinical spaces in Indigenous contexts. During the COVID-19 pandemic and amidst the absence of a working clinic, this study highlights how communication technologies like the radio have played a crucial role in helping women caregivers share healthcare information resources. 

Over the course of the research period, the Co-PI has presented preliminary findings at academic conferences with Latin American scholars working on concepts of dementia and aging.
